page.title: 19FARMER
page.content: At 6.00am I meet a cattle lorry at Stratford-on-Avon to travel round farms buying and collecting calves and returning to the lairage at Stratford about lunchtime.4 livestock officers are collecting at the same time. The calves in the lairage approx. 400 are sorted into breeds, i.e. Hereford, Friesian, Charalais, Limousin, and Simmental, and graded for quality. They are then sorted into matching batches and loaded back into the cattle lorries and sent out to calf rearers to be reared for beef and sold to butchers in 12 to 18 months time. Then the livestock movement papers have to be filled in at the office. I return home to Chaceley at 7.00pm. I then take my two dogs for a walk to an orchard in the village which I rent from a farmer to keep our two horses in while my wife cooks our meal.
